metadata.synopsis:
Avatar attempts to rest on the first night, and reflects on what has happened on the nautiloid.

JLatino: Look at cinematic context for mocap direction

19.speaker: Narrator
19.text: *Falling into your trance should have been as easy as breathing, yet peace eludes you.*

201.speaker: Narrator
201.text: *You picture the Feywild in its colourful glory, the joy of all seasons flourishing at once.*

25.speaker: Narrator
25.text: *Fire spills across your thoughts: dragon's breath. The tadpole slithers, twisting deeper into your skull.*

239.speaker: Narrator
239.text: *Your head is about to burst. The memory consumes your mind, corrupting the trance.*

219.speaker: Player
219.text: You have walked your dreams countless times before. Will this memory to pass.

96.speaker: Narrator
96.text: *The flames cool, dispelled as the image you know emerges again: wild, glorious magic.*

302.speaker: Narrator
302.text: *As the trance stabilises, your breath deepens. Be it cure or cage, something must be done about the tadpole.*

180.speaker: Narrator
180.text: *Every night that passes is another night the monster inside you grows.*

134.speaker: Player
134.text: Refuse to break. Anything can be endured in the trance.

150.speaker: Narrator
150.text: *The flames fall away, a mere illusion. You are one with the Feywild again, agleam in revelry.*

272.speaker: Narrator
272.text: *Hell surrounds you, flames licking at your body. The tadpole in your head convulses.*

222.speaker: Narrator
222.text: *Agony bursts behind your eyes, and the whole world goes dark.*
222.context: CinematicNodeContext: The elf player collapses from their trance, passing out. Fade to black.

37.speaker: Narrator
37.text: *You seek rest, but an active mind refuses you.*

129.speaker: Narrator
129.text: *Your mission should be your focus: finding a githyanki crèche, using a zaith'isk device to silence the ghaik parasite.*

0.speaker: Narrator
0.text: *Instead, recent memories overwhelm you: the kith'raki attacking the nautiloid; warring demons and devils; the twitching ghaik tadpole.*

252.speaker: Narrator
252.text: *Your head twinges. Is it the tadpole, you wonder? Had you imagined it - or were you soon to turn?*

116.speaker: Narrator
116.text: *'Suffering is not a curse, but a gift'. So Kith'rak Urlon had taught you.*

111.speaker: Narrator
111.text: *You will take this chance to overcome and ascend. Even the kith'raki will bow to you.*

168.speaker: Narrator
168.text: *Your thoughts turn to courage; a deep sleep soon follows.*

182.speaker: Narrator
182.text: *No exercise had prepared you for such extraordinary circumstances.*

36.speaker: Player
36.text: Imagine yourself beheading the very ghaik that had infected you.

158.speaker: Narrator
158.text: *You can almost feel its thick skull in your grasp, almost smell its silver blood clogging the air.*

206.speaker: Narrator
206.text: *You offer the head to Vlaakith, your queen. She hands you a sword of silver in return.*

5.speaker: Narrator
5.text: *Agitation overcomes imagination. Like it or not, the ghaik has bested you this day.*

300.speaker: Narrator
300.text: *You fall into fitful sleep, your dreams dominated by the blood-lakes of Hell and snarling ghaik.*

283.speaker: Player
283.text: Shut your mind to all thought.

131.speaker: Narrator
131.text: *You drive away all fears, and give yourself to the darkness. A deep sleep soon follows.*

257.speaker: Narrator
257.text: *There is no conquering the agitation. Like it or not, mind flayers have bested you this day.*

53.speaker: Player
53.text: I did it. After ten long years in the Hells, I'm fucking free.

2.speaker: Player
2.text: The air smells so much better here. And the breeze, and the trees, and the everything of it all. I could die now, and that'd be all right.

226.speaker: Narrator
226.text: *You can't hide it, even from yourself: you are deeply unsettled by that thing in your brain, and you haven't a clue how to cure it.*

178.speaker: Player
178.text: I'll figure something out. I always do.

171.speaker: Player
171.context: NodeContext: Yawning as she falls asleep reassuring herself.

294.speaker: Player
294.text: Uh, there was that one time with the three-tusked orthon...

88.speaker: Player
88.text: Will you leave that alone? It was five years ago, and the scar's almost healed.

93.speaker: Player
93.text: How do I turn you off? Oh wait, I know.
93.context: NodeContext: Yawning as she falls asleep reassuring herself.

43.speaker: Player
43.text: While I'm at it, I better find a way to turn down this inferno blazing in my heart.

273.speaker: Player
273.text: Dammon seems to've made a good start. I ought to keep him close.

293.speaker: Player
293.text: Really close. And then, next time he leans in to listen to my heart, I take his chin in my hand and I lift his face to meet mine and I - stop it, brain! This isn't the time! Is it?

115.speaker: Player
115.text: So I take his chin in my hand and I lift his face to meet mine and his face softens, like he's seeing me for the first time. 'Karlach...' he says, straightening.

210.speaker: Player
210.text: He puts his hand over mine, steps closer to me. Hand on my waist now as he leans in and kisses me so softly, like he's savouring each sensation.

264.speaker: Player
264.text: His hand moves lower, and he pulls me even closer toward him. I'm all nerves now, all starry, as my head explodes, showering him with skull fragments to reveal a mass of tentacles - OH GODS!

30.speaker: Player
30.text: Retreat. Abort. Go back. Ugh - why?

183.speaker: Player
183.text: Don't you have enough to worry about? Go to sleep for fuck's sake.

230.speaker: Player
230.text: Fucking Zariel. Mutilated me before I even knew what was happening. But I'll have this bloody heart out. Or turned off. Or whatever.

212.speaker: Player
212.text: Then I'm horizontalling my way around Baldur's Gate, from halfling poet to goliath berserker, until the gods themselves step in.

155.speaker: Player
155.text: Better not to go there. Plenty of time to fantasise about the future once I'm sure I've got a future.

157.speaker: Player
157.text: O-ho yes. Let's paint a picture. A halfling, a barbarian, and Karlach...

133.speaker: Player
133.text: Sweet silver-tongued halfling perched on my lap - I'll have one hand up her skirt, she'll have one down my top, when there's a knock at the door.

260.speaker: Player
260.text: He doesn't wait for my reply - it's... Logus... and all ten feet of him are back from the hunt. He steadies a brace of rabbits against the wall and sees us tangled up when - wait! No! Brain! This isn't the time... is it?

181.speaker: Player
181.text: Logus saunters over to me and...Liza. We startle. Didn't know he'd be back so soon. 'Let's move this to the bedroom, he grumbles.'

149.speaker: Player
149.text: Liza nods. I smile. I hoist her into my arms, use my free arm to pull Logus in closer. I kiss his neck, slowly, as my face suddenly blows out and my six writhing tentacles latch around his - OH GODS!

113.speaker: Player
113.text: What if the gods aren't even real?

233.speaker: Player
233.text: I've got a lot of living to do from here on out. Better rest up.

9.speaker: Player
9.text: Yes. Rest. Sleep. Peace. Ugh, I don't want to sleep! I want to be alive!

128.speaker: Player
128.text: Can't wait to eat some roasted chicken. Stand on a sea cliff. Touch someone - oh gods! Touch!

249.speaker: Player
249.text: Do not go there, Karlach. Not unless you want to burn this camp down.

253.speaker: Player
253.text: Not quite. Got a mind flayer tadpole in the head to worry about, don't we?

103.speaker: Player
103.text: A minor inconvenience. I'll find a way to get it removed.

66.speaker: Player
66.text: I'm never going back. Not for anything, not ever.

23.speaker: Player
23.text: Fuck no I'm not. I've suffered enough for five Karlachs - and I've had enough.

97.speaker: Narrator
97.text: *Rest eludes you as you stare at the wrong side of the stars.*

86.speaker: Narrator
86.text: *The ghaik larva is curled up in your skull, no doubt pleased with itself.*

151.speaker: Narrator
151.text: *Without a cure, you cannot restore your honour before your queen, Vlaakith.*

27.speaker: Player
27.text: Contemplate peace. Death can be sought in battle if purification is too far.

205.speaker: Narrator
205.text: *You picture a silver blade cleaving through ghaik and their thralls, one after another.*

101.speaker: Narrator
101.text: *Every cut is meditation. It reshapes the world to Vlaakith's will.*

213.speaker: Narrator
213.text: *Sleep comes as you count the fields of the dead, soon to grow.*

78.speaker: Narrator
78.text: *Every day this abomination is in your head, you put others at risk.*

203.speaker: Narrator
203.text: *There is no peace in that truth, only an unease that steals away any chance of sleep.*

309.speaker: Player
309.text: Rage fills you. Turn the feeling to higher purpose.

89.speaker: Narrator
89.text: *Every abomination would be gutted and burned to ash.*

223.speaker: Narrator
223.text: *Your anger is clarifying, pure and bright. It burns away all doubt.*

7.speaker: Narrator
7.text: *As the fire settles, tension bleeds from your body.*

189.speaker: Narrator
189.text: *Tomorrow, you will fight harder than ever before.*

214.speaker: Narrator
214.text: *You have been enslaved like your ancestors! Rage sparks to hatred.*

91.speaker: Narrator
91.text: *It burns relentlessly, like a red dragon's breath scorching you from the inside out.*

38.speaker: Narrator
38.text: *Stripped raw and restless, you find no peace that night.*

231.speaker: Player
231.text: Shame claws at you like rot. Are you a failure?

217.speaker: Narrator
217.text: *No. You would only be a failure if you stop fighting.*

274.speaker: Narrator
274.text: *Your honour can be restored before Vlaakith. It would be restored.*

58.speaker: Narrator
58.text: *Resolve strengthened, you fall into a deep slumber.*

224.speaker: Narrator
224.text: *You have prepared all your life to fight the ghaik. You dream of presenting one of their vile heads to Vlaakith in Tu'narath!*

191.speaker: Narrator
191.text: *How were you caught off-guard on the nautiloid? What was the crucial mistake?*

170.speaker: Narrator
170.text: *Without answers, you lay haunted for the rest of the night.*

177.speaker: Narrator
177.text: *As you writhe with sickly dreams, a deep dread floods you.*
177.context: CinematicNodeContext: Restlessly, the Dark Urge keeps tossing and fretting in their bed.

45.speaker: Narrator
45.text: *Though you have a tadpole, you know your broken mind is not like the others who bear the worm.*

21.speaker: Narrator
21.text: *A few scraps of the past come back to you now and then, but you can never quite tell where the knowledge comes from.*

54.speaker: Narrator
54.text: *Inexplicable violent yearnings overwhelm all other thoughts. Who could you possibly be, to be their vessel?*

308.speaker: Player
308.text: Think upon your heritage - is there truth hidden there?

235.speaker: Narrator
235.text: *The ancestral knowledge of your dragon-clan is diluted amid the liquid hate in your blood.*

100.speaker: Narrator
100.text: *Images of the Underdark's famed torments sometimes flicker in your head, but your place amongst your kin seems long-lost.*

10.speaker: Narrator
10.text: *Do you feel jolly? Aren't you meant to feel jolly? You don't make a very good gnome.*

185.speaker: Narrator
185.text: *It must have been a very long time since you were among your kind.*

61.speaker: Narrator
61.text: *When you try to think of a home your mind twists itself back to indulge in the delights of the day.*

132.speaker: Narrator
132.text: *You have been fighting since birth, such as Vlaakith preaches, but you feel little connection to any crèche. Barely a call to your queen.*

121.speaker: Narrator
121.text: *The comforts of the mine, a simple life, somehow you doubt you led. They don't call to you.*

79.speaker: Narrator
79.text: *The magma of Hell's knowledge sometimes bubbles up in your brain's crater, but never reaches a true fire.*

237.speaker: Narrator
237.text: *Your kinsfolk are found everywhere, aren't they? It doesn't narrow much down.*

312.speaker: Player
312.text: Contemplate your craft - why do you have the skills you do?

94.speaker: Narrator
94.text: *The oath you awoke with is some faded instinct. What does it even stand for?*

62.speaker: Narrator
62.text: *Nature provides some soft comforts, but your draw to it is only some faded instinct.*

31.speaker: Narrator
31.text: *The call to song is a hollow joy. You are more suited to death's dirge.*

127.speaker: Narrator
127.text: *All your education, your knack for your spells is only present as some distant instinct.*

120.speaker: Narrator
120.text: *The rages in your heart arise as an ancient instinct - your skill in the fray is but a long-lost muscle memory.*

186.speaker: Narrator
186.text: *Though you know how to call to order, hold a line and wield a blade, you are doing so out of habit and a forgotten instinct.*

70.speaker: Narrator
70.text: *The worship of your God feels an ancient fool's errand you are only following out of habit. When you call to the skies, there is no answer.*

238.speaker: Narrator
238.text: *You are fortunate your sorceries come from your instincts and not your mangled head.*

6.speaker: Narrator
6.text: *Whatever deal you made with your patron still stands, but they are in your magics, not in your mind.*

98.speaker: Narrator
98.text: *The lingering traces of your battle-intuitions are there. But the sly Urge within calls you to use them for harm.*

118.speaker: Narrator
118.text: *For a monk, you do hyperventilate an awful lot.*

277.speaker: Narrator
277.text: *The frost of the mountain, the sand of the beach, the mulch of the swamp. There are hints of the trails left. But they are far away.*

161.speaker: Narrator
161.text: *A friend of daggers all your skills match those of a hot-blooded killer.*

284.speaker: Player
284.text: Probe your mind - what thoughts stand out the most?

275.speaker: Player
275.text: The answer is simple: you must be Death itself.

136.speaker: Narrator
136.text: *There are many, many more kills ahead of you. That is you. A killer.*

75.speaker: Narrator
75.text: *You recall waking up hearing the pounding war drum of blood.*

42.speaker: Narrator
42.text: *How much you treasured the sight of the first corpse you touched.*

207.speaker: Narrator
207.text: *The crack of that guard's twice-broken legs.*

311.speaker: Narrator
311.text: *The delicacy of the jay's severed wings.*

135.speaker: Narrator
135.text: *The waggling stump you left of that wizard's arm...*

188.speaker: Player
188.text: Swear to resist these sick Urges, whatever the cost.

16.speaker: Narrator
16.text: *There must be a way through this red fog.*

278.speaker: Player
278.text: Lean deeper into your foul imaginations.

192.speaker: Narrator
192.text: *Your body feels aroused imagining a broken twisted neck, and a thrill thinking of a trailing intestine.*

71.speaker: Narrator
71.text: *As these images flood your mind, you fall soundly asleep like a babe in arms.*
71.context: CinematicNodeContext: DU falls asleep/trances if elf

202.speaker: Player
202.text: Wonder - why are these memories so beautiful?

290.speaker: Narrator
290.text: *How cruel your old life must have been. What could have happened to make you forget?*

276.speaker: Player
276.text: Fret - there is worse in your head than a tadpole.

41.speaker: Narrator
41.text: *Instinct tells you, you must protect yourself from you. Discover yourself, before it is too late.*

82.speaker: Narrator
82.text: *As you fall asleep, you are a shivering and shaking mess.*
82.context: CinematicNodeContext: DU falls asleep/trances if elf

154.speaker: Player
154.text: The answer is bleak: you were once someone awful.

241.speaker: Narrator
241.text: *Gazing up at the night sky, you try to will yourself to sleep.*

292.speaker: Narrator
292.text: *Useless - you can't stop thinking of Shar's sacred mission.*

267.speaker: Narrator
267.text: *Protect the artefact. Find your contact in Baldur's Gate. Fulfil Shar's command.*

117.speaker: Player
117.text: Reach for the artefact, hidden among your belongings.

269.speaker: Narrator
269.text: *Its weight reassures you. Shar's will and your destiny, right in your grasp.*

173.speaker: Narrator
173.text: *So many brothers and sisters sacrificed for it. Only you remain.*

187.speaker: Narrator
187.text: *... you and the vile creature inside you. The mere thought of it makes you shiver.*

56.speaker: Narrator
56.text: *You have to rid yourself of the tadpole. Shar herself is counting on you.*

216.speaker: Narrator
216.text: *If sleep won't come to you, at least darkness will.*

138.speaker: Player
138.text: Shut your eyes and silently thank Shar for the night's beauty.

199.speaker: Narrator
199.text: *You hear only your own thoughts. Shar's presence won't come to you - why?*

33.speaker: Narrator
33.text: *You have fulfilled her will - retrieved the artefact for her. Everyone has perished but you.*

102.speaker: Narrator
102.text: *... you, and your parasite. You are tainted now. Imperfect.*

124.speaker: Narrator
124.text: *You have to rid yourself of the tadpole. Then Shar will come to you - honour you as you honour her.*

289.speaker: Player
289.text: Pray to Shar. Her blessing will help you weather the trials ahead.

67.speaker: Narrator
67.text: *Only the sounds of the wilderness answer.*

243.speaker: Player
243.text: Try to remember what came before the mission.

251.speaker: Narrator
251.text: *Your memories are foggy - as your mission requires them to be: Shar's secrets are precious.*

105.speaker: Narrator
105.text: *As precious as sleep, and the night's oblivion.*

167.speaker: Player
167.text: Let your thoughts turn to the crash.

172.speaker: Narrator
172.text: *... all nothing compared to what came before. Compared to the tadpole.*

228.speaker: Narrator
228.text: *It's still inside you. Does it watch the night sky even now, through your eyes?*

144.speaker: Narrator
144.text: *You have to get rid of it. You have to survive. You are the only one left to ensure Shar's glory.*

261.speaker: Narrator
261.text: *The dark is familiar, but not comforting. It is a struggle to sink into your trance, weaving together memory, ambition, and purpose.*

8.speaker: Narrator
8.text: *You picture a cup, ancient and elven: priceless. Drinking from it honours the dead - those lost to Lolth's predation.*

153.speaker: Narrator
153.text: *Fire spills across your thoughts: dragon's breath. The tadpole slithers, twisting deeper into your skull.*

190.speaker: Narrator
190.text: *Your head is about to burst. The memory consumes your mind, corrupting the trance.*

268.speaker: Player
268.text: You have walked your dreams countless times before. Will this memory to pass.

166.speaker: Narrator
166.text: *The flames cool, dispelled as the image you know emerges again: blood and darkness.*

204.speaker: Player
204.text: Refuse to break. Anything can be endured in the trance.

77.speaker: Narrator
77.text: *The fire fades, a meaningless distraction. You hold the cup again, ignoring the crack along its belly, and drink.*

123.speaker: Narrator
123.text: *As the trance stabilises, your breath deepens. Be it cure or cage, something must be done about the tadpole.*

81.speaker: Narrator
81.text: *Every night that passes is another night the monster inside you grows.*

280.speaker: Narrator
280.text: *The flames fall away, a mere illusion. You sit the dark again, beside Lolth's majesty.*

143.speaker: Narrator
143.text: *Hell surrounds you, flames licking at your body. The tadpole in your head convulses.*

240.speaker: Narrator
240.text: *Agony bursts behind your eyes, and the whole world goes dark.*

20.speaker: Narrator
20.text: *The vision in your mind is simple: a stone altar to Lolth, the knife upon it bloody with sacrifice.*

285.speaker: Narrator
285.text: *A calm night is a mercy, yet your eyes refuse to stay closed.*

3.speaker: Narrator
3.text: *Every time they flicker shut, the tadpole seems to twitch behind them.*

46.speaker: Narrator
46.text: *Dragons, gith, and the Hells themselves have come after you. Yet it is this creature that lingers in your skull.*

184.speaker: Player
184.text: Focus. Finding a cure is all that matters.

83.speaker: Narrator
83.text: *And you will find it, no matter the cost.*

288.speaker: Narrator
288.text: *Your life is your own. No wriggling tadpole is going to change that.*

296.speaker: Narrator
296.text: *Sleep claims you, determination buoyed by gentle dreams.*

194.speaker: Player
194.text: You have to learn to control the tadpole. You sense it can grant you powers.

297.speaker: Narrator
297.text: *All you have to do is turn the tables - cage the creature before it cages you.*

122.speaker: Narrator
122.text: *You wonder if it could hear these thoughts - if it knows you're planning a rebellion.*

68.speaker: Narrator
68.text: *Let it listen. You will dream of all the ways to make this power your own.*

200.speaker: Player
200.text: Force the tadpole out of your mind. Think of home instead.

271.speaker: Narrator
271.text: *You belong with your people, down in the dark that never fades.*

139.speaker: Narrator
139.text: *Your people have survived the drow, the duergar, and every monster the Underdark has to offer. A mind flayer is nothing.*

28.speaker: Narrator
28.text: *Under the strange and open sky, sleep claims you.*

195.speaker: Narrator
195.text: *Yet the tadpole is in the dark too. Dozens of them, crawling towards you as a mind flayer held your skull in its psionic grip.*

47.speaker: Narrator
47.text: *Disgust churns deep in your stomach, leaving you resigned to a night without sleep.*

73.speaker: Player
73.text: Force the tadpole out of your mind. Think of home instead.

34.speaker: Narrator
34.text: *Baldur's Gate feels almost like a dream, after everything that has happened to you.*

50.speaker: Narrator
50.text: *Yet it is a dream of hope. You may be countless miles away, but it isn't an impossible journey.*

59.speaker: Narrator
59.text: *You will see those gates again. That promise sinks deep into your heart as your eyes drift shut.*

104.speaker: Narrator
104.text: *Except all you can picture is citizens with their skulls splintering open, tentacles sprouting from broken mouths.*

140.speaker: Narrator
140.text: *Their empty, alien eyes haunt you through a night of fitful sleep.*

146.speaker: Player
146.text: The tadpole influences you. Perhaps you might influence it in return...

303.speaker: Narrator
303.text: *You focus on that spot of pain from when it slipped behind your eye, to where it now lurks.*

298.speaker: Narrator
298.text: *You cannot prod it, but you can make it clear that you are watching. What is there to fear when it is the one stuck inside you?*

196.speaker: Narrator
196.text: *It is a minor victory, but enough to soothe you to sleep.*

193.speaker: Narrator
193.text: *The thought is punished by a spike of pain driven right between your eyes.*

291.speaker: Narrator
291.text: *The agony refuses to fade until you collapse against your bedroll in a cold sweat.*

301.speaker: Narrator
301.text: *You try to rest, but your mind won't settle.*
301.context: CinematicNodeContext: Player lying on his side, turns to lie on back

307.speaker: Narrator
307.text: *Just yesterday you were seducing a young noble, luring him to your master's lair.*

107.speaker: Narrator
107.text: *Today? You'd been kidnapped by mind flayers, chased through Hell by dragons, and thrown out of a burning ship.*

137.speaker: Narrator
137.text: *And you felt the sun on your skin...*

295.speaker: Player
295.text: Recall the light's comforting warmth. It's been an eternity.

125.speaker: Narrator
125.text: *You wonder if your ability to walk in the sun is a side effect of the tadpole the mind flayer put in your eye. It must be?*

32.speaker: Narrator
32.text: *All you know for sure is, given time, it will turn you into one of them.*

80.speaker: Narrator
80.text: *Getting rid of the tadpole will mean returning to the darkness. Unless...*

51.speaker: Narrator
51.text: *... unless you understand it. Master it. Which means finding an expert.*

74.speaker: Player
74.text: Focus on the problem - who would know the most about this?

229.speaker: Narrator
229.text: *You mentally shuffle through places likely to have an expert in mind flayers. Candlekeep? Neverwinter? Menzoberranzan? Baldur's Gate...*

159.speaker: Narrator
159.text: *Baldur's Gate is close to your master's coven, but also home to amazing scholars. Still, that's a problem for the morning.*
159.context: CinematicNodeContext: Brings arms down to side to sleep

152.speaker: Narrator
152.text: *You try to focus, but all you can see are the menacing eyes of a mind flayer.*

248.speaker: Player
248.text: Roll over, push it all from your mind.

90.speaker: Narrator
90.text: *You think on the day. The sunshine. Being alive - more or less.*

85.speaker: Narrator
85.text: *Despite everything, you relax into peaceful meditation, satisfied with all that's happened. Perhaps you wouldn't sleep so well if you knew what was coming.*

110.speaker: Player
110.text: Close your eyes. Relax. Imagine dragging your old master into the sunlight.

64.speaker: Narrator
64.text: *You smile, meditating on the flames that engulf his cruel face.*
64.context: CinematicNodeContext: Brings arms down to side to sleep

244.speaker: Narrator
244.text: *You close your eyes and try to focus on his delightful screams, but they quickly turn into your own. They only stop when tentacles burst from your mouth.*

246.speaker: Narrator
246.text: *You shudder, resigning yourself to whatever dark rest awaits you.*

69.speaker: Player
69.text: Think about your master. He'll be furious you didn't bring him dinner.

263.speaker: Narrator
263.text: *He'll believe you if you tell him what happened. But he won't forgive.*

87.speaker: Narrator
87.text: *Of course - you might already be a mind flayer by the time you return to Cazador.*

163.speaker: Narrator
163.text: *You could try getting rid of the tadpole, but that probably means returning to the darkness. Unless...*

287.speaker: Player
287.text: Consider the tadpole. Can a vampire spawn even become a mind flayer?

99.speaker: Narrator
99.text: *The worm in your head might not even have an appetite for undead meat.*

270.speaker: Narrator
270.text: *Until you know more about the tadpole, you can't be sure how much danger you're in.*

12.speaker: Narrator
12.text: *You have to understand it. Master it. Which means you need to find an expert.*
